newsitem.title: FRANCE: Havas, Gle des Eaux bid for SFP.
newsitem.headline: Havas, Gle des Eaux bid for SFP.

text.p: French media giant Havas and utility Compagnie Generale des Eaux announced on Tuesday a joint bid for state-owned film production company Societe Francaise de Production (SFP).

"The Havas and Generale des Eaux groups are to make a joint offer in which each will take an equal share for SFP, the production company now in the course of privatisation," the two companies said in a statement.
They gave no financial details about their offer.
"We are giving no financial details for the simple reason that we want to present them to the unions and the privatisation committee," a Generale des Eaux spokesman told Reuters.
He said those details would be presented "in the coming days or weeks."
Earlier Havas had been associated with a separate bid by Belgian company LBO Convoy group while Generale des Eaux supported a bid by William Butler's Global Studios.
The two companies, which already cooperate in other areas, had decided it was in their mutual interest to team up instead for SFP, a Generale des Eeaux spokesman said.
A third bidder is former SFP head Jacques Cressant, acting in association with a group of presenter-producers.
Generale des Eaux and Havas said "synergies with SFP will be realised through subsidiaries of the two groups in which they hold majority interest."
Those two companies are ITI/Tele Images, a production company belonging to Groupe Havas and Generale d'Images which belongs to Generale des Eaux.

Links between the two groups and their involvement in the audiovisual sector meant "they are in a position to implement a plan for the long-term development of SFP which is likely to be approved by staff," the companies said.
The French finance ministry had been due to choose a bidder by October 10 but that decision has been delayed.

The European Commission ruled earlier this month that France had illegally granted 1.1 billion francs ($212.3 million) in subsidies to SFP between 1993 and early 1996. It is unclear whether the money will have to be repaid. ($1=5.182 French Franc)
